physDesc.p: The letter consists of two sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of the first and one side of the second. At the top of the second sheet (page 3) there is a page number in the center, the letters “R.A.” on the top left, and the date on the top right.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I feel very badly to think that I have not yet thanked you for your bully article in the July “Egoist.” The reason has been owing to a chapter of misfortunes. In the first place, Mrs. Russell was taken quite ill and threatened with typhoid fever, and went to bed, with two doctors and a nurse. It was three weeks before she was able to go out to Salt Lake City, where she is going to spend the summer with her family. During that time, I was of course very anxious and very much occupied. I tried to be with her all day, and translate those French poems for the appendix of my book all night. The result is that Nemesis has pounced upon me in the shape of violent indigestion and I have been feeling perfectly rotten and utterly incapable of writing anything.

I got up here, where I have not been for three years, to find the roof leaking like a sieve, and the avenue almost impassible from the terrible rains we have been having this year. I am feeling a little better now, although I am only up to about half my usual working capacity. And the first thing I do, I am going to thank you awfully for that article. I think it excellent. My only criticism would be that I hate to have attention called to the affluent side of my existence, a side of which I take so little cognizance myself. I am particularly glad that you liked “The Bath,” and what you said about it was just the right thing. Personally, I think your critical articles are quite perfect. They never seem overloaded and they are always interesting.

I have just finished one on you for the September “Little Review.” It is not as good as I wish it were. That is where my health came in; but it is the best I could do under the agitating circumstances in which I have been living.

A man dined with me last night, a poor, little hunchback, who is supposed to be very clever. He is one of the contributors to “The New Republic.” He told me he particularly liked your “Childhood,” that it was the best thing you had done. But I shall let my criticism of it stand, because I do think that technically perhaps it is not quite as irreproachable as your other things. I hope you will like the article and will not mind the few little criticisms I have made. You see, I do not think an unmitigated puff ever goes down with the public, and it seemed better to say exactly what I thought than have it read like a puff. As this is your own method, I do not think you will mind my using it.
I forwarded a letter from you yesterday to Fletcher. He wrote me a little while ago that he expected to go still farther West, but that his plans were still uncertain.

This is a lovely place. I wish you and Hilda were here. For two summers I have been away, as you know, and its beauty strikes me all over newly. It looks like Scotland with its lakes and mountains. In fact, I believe that geographically it and Scotland are first cousins.

I keep sending you clippings from time to time. I trust you get them all right. I cannot tell you how I miss my summer with you people and how homesick I am to see you all. I think one reason for my collapse this Spring is that just about that time I am used to taking the sea voyage and having a lot of new and pleasant stimulation; and this year, I have just kept steadily to the grind-stone right along.

By the way, our book is going very well. We have sold 575 copies since the first of April, and our royalties are magnificent, $28.62. I am enclosing a money-order which represents yours and Hilda’s share. I am also sending Lawrence and Flint theirs. Fletcher, of course, I am paying by cheque. Mr. Greenslet tells me what we lead the New Poetry Series so far. I think the notice in the “London Times” singularly disagreeable; but then, the “London Times” is always nasty to me, so I do not mind.
Tell me how you like that poem of mine in the August “Little Review.” Fletcher and I rather like it. No more for the present; I have to go back to my proof reading.

By the way, I have spoken to Brown about an exchange advertisement with you for the “Poetry Journal” and he is delighted with the idea. But there is not the faintest use for your applying to “The New Republic.” They are highly endowed and are not looking for bargains, and they are altogether too stodgy to make any such arrangement. It is very good of you to want an advance copy of my book. I will send you the proofs when I get a complete set, and you can read it at your leisure.

closer.p: With lots of love to you and Hilda,
